paragraph_1@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text:
§cTHIS VERSION OF THIS ADD-ON WILL ONLY WORK FOR MINECRAFT §a1.21.2x §c(ex. §a1.21.20§c or §a1.21.21§c). 
If you are on a different version of minecraft, please update this pack to the correct version for the version of Minecraft that you are playing on. 
§eThis add-on breaks every medium-sized update (ex. 1.21.0, 1.21.20, 1.21.30, or 1.21.40) and must be updated whenever that happens. 
§bYour data will be preserved when updating the pack to a newer version.

paragraph_2_all_required_experimental_to.$text:
When setting up the add-on you must first make sure that you have the following experimental toggles enabled: 
Upcoming Creator Features
Beta APIs
Creator Cameras: New Third Person Presets
Creator Cameras: Focus Target Camera
Bundles

paragraph_2_other_recommended_settings@h.$text: It is also recommended to enable the "Education Edition" toggle.

paragraph_3a@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: To update the add-on on a world all you have to do is:

paragraph_3b@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text:
1. Get the .mcaddon file for the new version. 
2. Import it into minecraft. 
3. Go on the edit world screen for the world that you want to update the add-on on. 
4. Deactivate the old version of the add-on. 
5. Activate the new version of the add-on. (Make sure that you activate the behavior pack first or else it might glitch and show taht both the resource and behavior packs are on, when only the resource pack is on, which you will see if you go to the main menu and then back into the edit world screen again.)
6. Go back to the main menu. 
7. Go into the edit world screen again and insure that both the resource and behavior packs are active.

paragraph_3c@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: To update the add-on on a realm all you have to do is:

paragraph_3d@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text:
1. Get the .mcaddon file for the new version. 
2. Import it into minecraft. 
3. Download the world from the realm. 
4. Go on the edit world screen for the world that you just downloaded. 
5. Deactivate the old version of the add-on. 
6. Activate the new version of the add-on. 
7. Go back to the main menu. 
8. Go into the edit world screen again and insure that both the resource and behavior packs are active. 
9. Load up the world. (This is very important, if you don't do this then the packs won't actually add when you put the world back on to the realm.)
10. Save & Quit the world. 
11. Go to the realms settings screen.

paragraph_3e@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: 12. Select the currently active world and click edit.

paragraph_3f@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: 13. In the "Game Settings" section scroll down to the very bottom and click on replace world.

paragraph_3g@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: 14. Select the world that you just added the packs to.

paragraph_0@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: The debug stick works identical to the java edition one, you use to go to the next possible value of that block state, and sneak while using to go to the previous one, you hit the block to select the next block state type, and sneak while hitting the block to select the previous block state type, you can see a demonstration of this in the trailer video. The liquid clipped version allows you to also target liquid blocks.

paragraph_3@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: This is the same as the editor stick except it can't show you block info by sneaking and when you use it you can select which block to edit by entering its coordinates.

paragraph_5@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: This is the same as the editor stick except it can't show you block info by sneaking and when you use it you can select filtering options for which block that you are looking at will actually be selected.

paragraph_7@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: This opens up the main menu GUI.

paragraph_9@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: This allows you to enter a command into the GUI to run it, this can run commands that normally you would need to use an npc to run it, such as the §b§l/agent§r§r command.

paragraph_11@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: This allows you to enter some JavaScript code into the GUI to run it, this can run any JavaScript/Script API code.

paragraph_13@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: This opens up the player controller GUI.

paragraph_15@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: This opens up the entity controller GUI.

paragraph_17@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: This lets you get debug info about a player.

paragraph_19@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: This lets you get debug info about an entity.

paragraph_1@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: This section will be filled out in a future update.
This section will be filled out in a future update.

paragraph_0@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: §lTo use the majority of chat commands, you will first need to give yourself the canUseChatCommands tag.§r

paragraph_1@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: §lTo get notified whenever a player runs a chat command then just give yourself the getAllChatCommands tag.§r

paragraph_2@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Some chat commands require different tags than others, and some don't require any at all.

paragraph_3@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: The tags required to use each chat command can be configured in the Manage Commands section of the Main Menu.

paragraph_4@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Most chat commands default to requiring the canUseChatCommands tag.

paragraph_5@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Some commands like home, help, and tpa default to not requiring any tags to use them, so anyone can use them.

paragraph_6@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: You can also disable individual commands completely in the Manage Commands section of the main menu.

paragraph_7@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: For all built-in chat commands you can just type §b\help cmd§r followed by the name of the command and it will display what the command does, the syntax of it, and what any flag parameters on the command do. For example if you wanted to see how to use the giveb command you would do §b\help cmd giveb§r and for the replace command you would do §b\help cmd replace§r.

paragraph_0@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Some examples of parameters in a command would be [-tfsa], <player: target>, and [name: string] in the following command syntax:

paragraph_2@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: In the syntax of a command there are multiple ways a parameter can be written out:

paragraph_3@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Optional parameters are enclosed in square brackets like this: [name: string]

paragraph_4@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Note: Parameters written as a dash followed by a string of characters enclosed in square brackets (ex. [-tfsa] or [-z]) is not considered an optional parameter, this is a flags parameter.

paragraph_5@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: optional parameters are optional, you can either include them or not include them, however if you do not include them then any parameters after them cannot be included either, so in the following command:

paragraph_7@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: If you choose not to include the name parameter, then you cannot include the escapeCodesEnabled parameter either.

paragraph_8@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: So this means that this command syntax is actually like three separate syntaxes, you can do any of the following:

paragraph_12@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: Required parameters are enclosed in arrow brackets like this: <player: target>

paragraph_13@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: Required parameters are required, the parameter must be included.

paragraph_14@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: Ignorable parameters are enclosed in curly brackets like this: {includeEntities: boolean}

paragraph_15@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: Ignorable parameters are optional, but unlike optional parameters, if you don't include them, you can still include the parameters after them, so in the following command:

paragraph_17@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: Even if you choose not to include the name parameter, you can still include the escapeCodesEnabled parameter either.

paragraph_18@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: So this means that this command syntax is actually like four separate syntaxes, you can do any of the following:

paragraph_23@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: Ignorable parameters are written as a dash followed by a string of characters enclosed in square brackets like this: [-tfsa]

paragraph_24@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: For an ignorable parameter, it has no specified parameter type. Instead, you just either put nothing and ignore the parameter, or you put a dash followed by the flags you want to enable, each flag is its own unique character, you can type these characters in any order, and you can include any combination of them that you like, however if you put a dash there then you must include at least one flag.

paragraph_25@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: So, for the parameter [-tfsa] you could do any of the following examples:

paragraph_27@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: For all parameter categories except for flags parameters, a parameter will be written in one of the following formats inside of the parameter category's bracket type:

paragraph_32@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: Parameter restrictions are specified inside of square brackets after the parameter's type.

paragraph_33@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: Parameter restrictions are a comma-separated list of restrictions, each restriction is formatted as restrictionName=restrictionValue.

paragraph_34@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text:
An example of a parameter with parameter restrictions would be:
[size: number[?=1,??=1,min=-1000,max=1000,allowNaN=false,allowNegatives=false,precision=20]]

paragraph_37@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: This specifies the default value for the parameter, this will be used if it is not specified.

paragraph_39@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: This specified the value to be used for the parameter in the event of an error when parsing the parameter.

paragraph_41@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: The minimum value of the parameter.

paragraph_43@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: The maximum value of the parameter.

paragraph_45@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: The maximum length of the list parameter type or string parameter type.

paragraph_47@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: The maximum length of the strings and/or lists inside of the list parameter type.

paragraph_49@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: The maximum length of the strings inside of the list parameter type.

paragraph_51@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: The maximum length of the lists inside of the list parameter type.

paragraph_53@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: Indicates whether JavaScript escape codes are allowed.

paragraph_55@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: Indicates whether the number parameter type allows for Infinity and -Infinity to be used.

paragraph_57@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: Indicates whether the number parameter type allows for NaN to be used.

paragraph_59@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: Indicates whether negative number values are allowed in the number parameter type.

paragraph_61@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: Indicates the precision to be used when parsing the number parameter type. This means that the actually inputted number will be that same as that number with the javascript toPrecision() function ran on it with the precision set to the value of this restriction.

paragraph_63@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: Indicates whether this parameter can throw an error.

paragraph_65@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: The minimum number of targets for a target parameter type.

paragraph_67@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: The maximum number of targets for a target parameter type.

paragraph_69@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: Whether this string or boolean parameter must be in all lowercase.

paragraph_71@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: Whether this string or boolean parameter must be in all uppercase.

paragraph_73@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: Whether this string or boolean parameter must be in all lowercase.

paragraph_75@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: Whether this string or boolean parameter must be in all camelcase.

paragraph_77@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: Whether this string or boolean parameter must be in all titlecase.

paragraph_79@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: Whether this parameter type allows for multiple items.

paragraph_80@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: For an array this would determine if the array could have more than one item in it.

paragraph_81@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: For a target this would mean that it could have multiple targets.

paragraph_83@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: Whether or not this parameter is case-sensitive.

paragraph_5@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: A float, decimal, integer, Infinity, -Inifnity, or NaN.

paragraph_6@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: A float, decimal, integer, Infinity, or -Infinity.

paragraph_7@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: A boolean. (true or false, usually required to be lowercase)

paragraph_8@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text:
A string. Can be either a string of text with no spaces, or a JSON formatted string. (ex. "some text
another line of text \uE359 and the unicode character U+E359" or myStringOfText_With-0-Spaces)

paragraph_11@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: 1. {"a": 1, "b": "something", "c": true, "d": {"p": 95, "e": -99}, "e": [{"a": 54, "b": true}, [1, "a", true, false], 4, -9, true, false, null], "f": null, "g": -72}

paragraph_16@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: 6. "some text\nanother line of text \uE359 and the unicode character U+E359"

paragraph_17@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: 7. [1, 4, true, -7, false, "hi", "test", "to", "text\nnext line of text", {"a": 1, "b": 2}, [1, 4, false, "some"]]

paragraph_19@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: Example: [1, 4, true, -7, false, "hi", "test", "to", "text\nnext line of text", {"a": 1, "b": 2}, [1, 4, false, "some"]]

paragraph_21@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: Example: {"a": 1, "b": "something", "c": true, "d": {"p": 95, "e": -99}, "e": [{"a": 54, "b": true}, [1, "a", true, false], 4, -9, true, false, null], "f": null, "g": -72}

paragraph_22@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: A JSON formatted string. ex. "some text\nanother line of text \uE359 and the unicode character U+E359"

paragraph_23@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: A decimal, float, integer, Infinity, -Infinity, or NaN.

paragraph_25@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: A string of text that allows for spaces, does not need quotation marks.

paragraph_26@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: A string of text that allows for spaces and javascript escape codes, does not need quotation marks.

paragraph_30@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: A namespaced id of an item type, for example andexdb:debug_stick, or minecraft:grass, or netherreactor, or stick.

paragraph_31@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: A namespaced id of a block type, for example andexsa:diamond_crafting_table, or minecraft:grass_block, or glowingobsidian, or stone.

paragraph_32@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: A namespaced id of a block type, for example andexsa:diamond_crafting_table, or minecraft:grass_block, or glowingobsidian, or stone.

paragraph_33@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: A namespaced id of an item type, for example andexdb:debug_stick, or minecraft:grass, or netherreactor, or stick.

paragraph_36@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: A set of block states. Ex. ["infiniburn_bit"=false,"cardinal_direction"="north"]

paragraph_37@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: A set of coordinates, relative coordinates and caret notation are allowed.

paragraph_39@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: A set of coordinates, relative coordinates are allowed.

paragraph_42@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: The name or namespaced id of a dimension. Valid values are overworld, nether, the_end, minecraft:overworld, minecraft:nether, and minecraft:the_end.

paragraph_43@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: This parameter type means that the value you type in for it is the exact text that is inside of the {}. For example if the parameter type is {testabcd} then for the parameter you would type in testabcd.

paragraph_44@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: This parameter type means that it can actually be any of the parameter types separated by vertical lines | inside of the parentheses (). For example, if your parameter was [value: (number|(string|JSONArray)[maxLength=2])[?=5]] then for the parameter you could do a number, a string with a max length of 2, a JSONArray with a max length of 2, or nothing, and if you put nothing then it will just default to 5.

paragraph_1@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: This section will be filled out in a future update.

bullet_point_paragraph_1@how_to_play_com.$text: · Go to "Manage Commands", scroll down to and click "Custom".

bullet_point_paragraph_2@how_to_play_com.$text: · Set the command name, do not include the command prefix (like "\").

bullet_point_paragraph_3@how_to_play_com.$text: · Set the toggle to "Commands" or "javascript", which will change how you define the command's syntax later on (whether it runs normal vanilla commands or runs a command in javascript).

bullet_point_paragraph_4@how_to_play_com.$text: · "Command Version", "Formatting Code", and "Description" are used for the command's help documentation, and are not necessary for the command to work

bullet_point_paragraph_5@how_to_play_com.$text: · "Command Prefix" sets the command prefix for this command.

bullet_point_paragraph_6@how_to_play_com.$text: · Then click "Create Command", which will bring you back to the menu.

bullet_point_paragraph_7@how_to_play_com.$text: · Go back to the custom commands tab and click on your command. Click on "edit code". In the text box, enter your command or code (depending on the toggle you selected earlier).

bullet_point_paragraph_8@how_to_play_com.$text: · You can also use multiple commands at once by going back to your custom command and clicking "Edit Command". At the top, there is a slider to change the number of lines. Change the slider value to the number of commands you want, then after reentering the "Edit Code" tab, there will be a box for each command you want to run.

bullet_point_paragraph_9@how_to_play_com.$text: · In the "Edit Command" section you can turn on the "Automatic Parameter Evaluation" toggle and scroll down to the bottom text box where you can enter parameters for the command (like in `/say <text: string>`, the "<text: string>" is a parameter). More information on how to format these is in that menu. These can be accessed in your command syntax (step 8) by using "${param[#]}" in command mode or "param[#]" in javascript mode. String parameters support escape characters if they are in quotation marks: "<string>".

already_joined_section_header@how_to_pla.$text: §aHow do I ban a player (who has joined the world before)?§r

paragraph_1@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text:
1. Open the main menu (use "\mm")
2. Go to "Manage Players"
3. Go through the pages to find the player you wish to ban and click on them
4. Click "Manage Bans"
5. Enter the time and reason, and submit it

never_joined_section_header@how_to_play_.$text: §cHow do I ban a player who has never joined the world?§r

paragraph_2@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text:
1. Open the main menu (use "\mm")
2. Scroll down and click "Manage Bans"
3. Click "Add Name Ban"
4. Enter the players name, put in the time and reason, and submit it

bullet_point_paragraph_1@how_to_play_com.$text: · Go to "Moderation" and then click on "Anti-Spam"

bullet_point_paragraph_2@how_to_play_com.$text: · The toggle at the top turns on and off the anti-spam system, which will mute players who send too many messages too fast. Note that commands do not count as messages, but all other chat types do (sending unique messages at a fast pace will also trigger the system).

bullet_point_paragraph_3@how_to_play_com.$text: · The "Wait Time" box contains the amount of time (in seconds) that players will be muted for after triggering the anti-spam.

bullet_point_paragraph_4@how_to_play_com.$text: · The "Maximum Time Between Messages" box contains the amount of time (in seconds) that players need to wait between messages in order to not trigger the anti-spam.

bullet_point_paragraph_5@how_to_play_com.$text: · The "Message Count To Trigger Anti-Spam" slider sets the number of messages that must be sent too fast in order to trigger the anti-spam.

paragraph_0@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: You can make it so that specific players can bypass the anti-spam system by giving them the canBypassAntiSpam tag.
The home system allows players to set personal warps, regardless of their permissions. The home system is disabled by default, so make sure to turn it on in settings.

paragraph_1@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: A maximum number of homes per player can be set in "Main Menu -> Settings-> Home System Settings -> Maximum Homes per Player"

bullet_point_paragraph_0@how_to_play_com.$text: · Use `\home set <name>` to set a home to the place you are currently standing.

bullet_point_paragraph_1@how_to_play_com.$text: · Use `\gohome <name>` to teleport to a set home location

bullet_point_paragraph_2@how_to_play_com.$text: · Use `\home remove <name>` to remove a saved home location

bullet_point_paragraph_3@how_to_play_com.$text: · Use `\home list` to see all homes you currently have

bullet_point_paragraph_0@how_to_play_com.$text: · Any player can use the tp request system, regardless of permissions. The tp request system is disabled by default, so make sure to turn it on in settings.

bullet_point_paragraph_1@how_to_play_com.$text: · Use `\tpa <target>` to request to teleport to a player. This will send a message to that player. If they type "n" in chat or do nothing for 1 minute, the request will be denied. If they type "y" in chat, you will be teleported to them.

paragraph_1@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: The settings menu can be accessed either through the \mm command (you must have the canUseChatCommands tag to run it), or the andexdb:main_menu item (The main menu stick).
This settings section is for the main add-on settings.

paragraph_2@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: This settings section allows you to change things like the prefix for commands, valid prefixes for commands from other add-ons, the location to teleport players to then they use the \spawn command, etc.

paragraph_1@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: This settings section allows you to customize the chat ranks.
This section will be filled out in a future update.
